Now, our oppo- nents in this investigation have recourse to the question of limitatione in the following way: They assert—what is perlectly true—that sus· pensory action is taken where the loss is not recoverable in a suit for ownership, has others neatly explain through another suit for pos· session. Moreover, my opponente go on to make mention of the irreparable loss sullered by a sailor who merely has the power of detention and is now deprived ot that by an [adverse] decision, iand yet in a suit relating to detention the rule is explicitly laid down that an appeal to suspend the judgment should be granted, but 1 reply that the loss here is always reparable or else it is not loss. Lookl Either it is of his own loss on account ol passage money that the sailor speaks—but this passage money has been as· signed to him so that it he accepts it as being a fair amount, then he suffers no loss3 or, on the other hand, it he does not accept it, thinking it not a lair amount, he will recover the loss suffered by an hypothecary action, ¹‘by an actio in rem, by a suit to secure owner· ship. ¹Thus also in a suit involving detention the appeal is denied should the loss be reparable. But here either he has no such instructions from them, so that the loss is not to be con· sidered, because there is none, or else he has such instructions and will recover his loss by the institution of a separate suit.
